subject: Art
title: ISO & Sensor Sensitivity
description: Amplifying the sensor's signal when light is scarce â€” at a cost.

hook.text: ISO is volume for light. Low ISO (100-400): clean, detailed images in good light. High ISO (3200+): bright images in darkness, but with grain/noise â€” like turning up volume on a quiet recording.

buildup.text: ISO 100: base sensitivity, cleanest quality. Each doubling (200, 400, 800, 1600, 3200, 6400) doubles sensitivity but increases noise. Modern cameras handle ISO 3200 well; older cameras struggle above 800.

discovery.text: Best practice: use the lowest ISO that allows your desired aperture and shutter speed. ISO is the last resort â€” raise it only when you can't open the aperture wider or slow the shutter further.

twist.text: Film photographers chose their ISO before shooting (it was the film). Digital photographers can change ISO shot-by-shot. This flexibility is one of digital's biggest advantages â€” and it's easy to take for granted.

climax.text: Take the same photo at ISO 100, 1600, and 12800. Zoom to 100% and compare. The low ISO is pristine. The high ISO shows grain and lost detail. Knowing this trade-off helps you decide when noise is acceptable.

punchline.text: A noisy photo of a great moment beats a clean photo of nothing. ISO lets you capture what matters.

quiz.question: What is the trade-off of using high ISO?
options: Increased brightness but more noise/grain and reduced detail
